oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Lion, the Jackal, the Chersina angulata, and the Hyena. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-25. 8232-8251). The Lion and the Jackal throw mud at each other and as a result the Lion sits blinded at the water. The |go |go'ken (Chersina angulata, or angulate tortoise) wipes his eyes clean and the Lion eats her, putting her head into his bag. |go |go'ken's husband, the Hyena, offers the Lion some soup and puts the pot over the Lion's head and kills him. 1) p.8231v: |han=kass'o heard this story from his mother (|xabbi-an), 2) pp.8234v-8235v: see An ostrich eggshell, if left open, will attract snakes, 3) p.8235v: what the people call a lion and its movements, 4) p.8236v: the name of a woman; what is said when the white hair of the springbok is 'up'; on 'dipping up' water when it has rained, 5) p.8241v & 8242v: sorrow and grief (what the |xam and white men say); the drinking of soup, 6) p.8247v: brave men and cowards, 7) p.8250v: a man Tsatsi (|han=kass'o's maternal grandfather) told |han=kass'o about, 8) This story is found in Book VIII-25.
